title: A Fox, a Goose, and a Bag of Beans Logic Riddle

description.text:
Project Name: A Fox, a Goose, and a Bag of Beans Logic Riddle

Students are given 3D models to act out and try to solve a famous logic riddle about a goose, a fox, and a bag of beans. They are then shown a clip from The Simpsons that is a parody of this riddle.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

I measured the circumference of my pointer and ring fingers and then used the circumference = pi(diameter) formula to get the diameters of the circular holes needed to fit my fingers through. The size of these holes can be changed to match student’s fingers, but it is also okay to just leave them a little big, as they don’t need to match perfectly. I used Tinkercad to design the base with a rectangle and then cylinder holes. The bean bag was added using the cylinder and adding letters on top. The fox, goose, and farmer were first hand drawn and scanned. I then converted them to SVG files and imported them into Tinkercad.
CCSS

Overview & Background:
Students will get practice problem solving. Objectives:
Students will use their problem solving skills. According to Susanna Epp, (author of Discrete Mathematics with Applications) solving these types of puzzles will help develop a sense for the flow of deductive reasoning students will use later in mathematical proofs of all types. Epp, S. (1990). Discrete Mathematics with Applications. Belmont, California: Wadsworth Publishing Company. (1995) Discrete Mathematics with Applications, Second Edition. Boston, Massachusetts: PWS Publishing. Skills Learned (Standards):
CCSS.Math.Practice.MP1 Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them. Audiences:
There is no math background required for this activity, so it can be used at any time, probably starting in middle school and up. One suggestion is to use this as a first day of school activity to get students back to thinking about math, but in a fun way.

Step 1 Explain the riddle. It says that a farmer goes to market and buys a fox, a goose, and a bag of beans. To get home the farmer has to cross a river in a boat that can only hold himself plus one other item. Left alone the fox would eat the goose and the goose would eat the bag of beans. The goal is to figure out how the farmer can get everything across safely. Step 2 In groups of four ask students to solve this riddle. Students should be given the models to act out the situation as they try to solve the riddle. One solution is for the farmer to first take the goose to the other side. Next, he returns and brings the fox over. On the next return he brings the goose with him. Then he takes the bag of beans to the other side and returns. Finally he brings the goose back over. Step 3 Once a group has a solution, ask them if there are other solutions. One variation is to switch the roles of the fox and the bag of beans. Step 4 Have groups share their solution. Ask them why it is necessary for the goose to be brought over first. Essentially it works out this way because the goose can’t be left alone with either the fox or the beans. Step 5 Show students this clip from The Simpsons where Homer goes to the store to get rat poison to deal with a rat infestation. He is driving Maggie and their dog, Santa’s Little Helper, home. Homer gets distracted, which causes the car to go off a bridge. Homer needs to cross a river. There is a boat but it can only carry two items at a time. Maggie can’t be left alone with the poison because she may swallow it. Santa’s Little Helper can’t be left alone with Maggie because he may bite her. Homer has to figure out how to get everyone safely across. The clip can be seen here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lX4T7KxmAwU. There is also a discussion of the problem in this video or you can just show the clip from the show. Step 6 Have students figure out how this is equivalent to the previous riddle. To solve Homer’s riddle he first takes Maggie over to the other side. Then he returns and brings the poison over. He brings Maggie back to the other side and brings Santa’s Little Helper across. Finally, he returns and brings Maggie back over. In this version Maggie is equivalent to the goose, the poison is equivalent to the fox, and Santa’s Little Helper is equivalent to the bag of beans.
This activity will take around 25 minutes.
Students don’t need any background knowledge to do this activity.

This activity can be done without an assessment or can count for a participation grade.
Question (points)
Participation in solving the riddle (7)
Participation in presenting solution (3)
Total 10

title: Sphero Modular Puzzle Maze Blocks - Build your own robot maze to challenge your programming skills!

description.text:
I am fundraising for a Robotics Mentoring Program at Sachem East High School (https://www.donorschoose.org/project/robotics-and-programming-mentoring-progr/2045457/) and decided to put together some challenges for Sphero Robots.

This challenge is meant for Sphero Robots, but I bet It can be scaled up or down for other robots. It includes three different maze types that can be re-arranged to change the path Sphero will have to travel through to constantly challenge students with math and programming tasks.

The goal is to have high school students mentor elementary and middle school students in how to program Sphero through the maze with Spark Lab programming apps. This is an easy and fun way to have students learn math and programming, build social skills, and most of all have fun!

We were able to print these maze blocks at Camp Sachem's Summer Enrichment Program this summer using a Makerbot Replicator that we had on loan as part of a Federal Grant.

The size of these puzzle pieces allow them to easily store in a small flip top Sterilite container with the ability to stack 10 to 12 in a box. This is a necessity since our mentoring program will have to pack up onto a cart in order for us to be able to bring the robots and mazes from school to school. They are also able to be printed with any 6x6 or larger printer very easily and fairly quickly with low resolution. I recommend using masking tape on the backside of the seams to secure them together but I may try adhesive velcro and a 20"x20" coroplast or masonite board in the future so that younger students can arrange the mazes by themselves.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low

Infill:

50%

Overview:

Need a way to get young students excited about programming?
Use these maze blocks along with your Sphero robot and Lightning Lab in order to get program sphero through the maze!

Objectives:

Students will be able to problem solve through programming Sphero's speed, direction, time and distance in order to program Sphero through many different maze combinations.

Audiences:

This activity is intended for grades 2-8. My hope is that I can start up a mentoring program where high school students can teach programming skills to younger age students under a teachers supervision to deliver meaningful learning to all age groups.

Subjects:

Math, Science, Behavioral Science, Robotics, Linguistics, Technology

Standards

NYS MST Technology Standard 5.3: use a computer system to monitor and control external
events and/or systems.

Activity

Groups of 2-3 students will be able to use a Sphero Robot and a paired Tablet with the Lightning Lab app in order to write a program to get Sphero through the maze.

Start with one maze block and have the students write out what steps Sphero would have to take to get through it.

Discuss the variable such as direction/Heading (how does Sphero sense his direction? What does Heading mean?) speed (Why is the speed range 0-255?) and delay (How long should Sphero move before he gets to the next step?)

After the students master one Maze Puzzle Block you can add more and see how many blocks they can get through.

Alternate assignments can be used such as how fast can you get sphero through a specific maze, sensing collisions, and changing colors based on the maze block sphero is on.

Advances students can also create blocks of code based on the color of maze blocks and develop faster ways to program through any configuration of maze blocks!

Duration:

A basic Sphero maze programming challenge where the students can try to work up to programming through as many attached maze blocks as possible could be as little as 40 minutes, which is great if you want to travel to many schools. Our school district has 3 middle schools and almost a dozen elementary schools, so for the first year we would focus on just one lesson reaching out to as many students as we can to get them excited about programming.

Later lessons may include blocking code together and also racing through maze designs if time allows which would extend the duration to three 40 minute sessions.

Preparation:

In order to complete this activity you will need multiple printed maze puzzle blocks and a Sphero robot and paired bluetooth capable tablet per group. I recommend finding a comfortable carpeted or padded floor to work on to reduce wear and tear on the robots, tablets and maze blocks.

References:

https://sprk.sphero.com/
http://www.sphero.com/
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.sphero.sprk&hl=en

Handouts:

SPRK Lightning Lab Activity for Sphero Maze Puzzles PDF located in thing files

This activity is for an AP statistics class. Students design a coin and then perform an experiment and hypothesis test to see if it is fair or biased.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

I used Tinkercad and designed a quarter. You can allow students to choose the type of coin and then look up dimensions. A quarter has a 24.26 mm diameter and a width of 1.75 mm. The cylinder can be shaped to that size and then decorated however students choose. I purposely did one side with an indentation and one side with letters popping out in hopes of showing this coin is unfair.
NGSS CCSS

Project: Is My Coin Fair? Students will get practice performing a Chi-Square Goodness of Fit test. Objectives Students will learn what a fair coin is and, after seeing everyone’s coin and results, get a feel for which coins were designed to be fair and which were biased. Standards Students get practice performing a Chi-Square Goodness of Fit test.

First, students will design a coin, using the standard size of a quarter, nickel, dime, or penny. Next, they will answer questions about running a hypothesis test, such as what the null and alternative hypotheses are, the degrees of freedom, and the critical value. Once the coin is finished printing they will perform an experiment by flipping it 50 times. They will then calculate the test statistic and conclude if their coin was fair or biased. There is an optional extension to have students try to design a fair coin or try to design a biased coin and then run through the hypothesis test again.

• Chi-Square
  • Fit Test

This activity can take one day if you have enough printers available to students. The print time for my quarter sized coin was 9 minutes. If there is only one printer or if you do the extension, you may need to split it into two days to allow for printing time.
Students should have already learned hypothesis testing including the Chi-Square Goodness of Fit test.

Here is a sample rubric to use with the worksheet.
Question (points)
1 (1)
2 (1)
3 (1)
4 (1)
5 (1)
6 (1)
7 (3)
Making the coin (1)
Total 10

If you would like to have students learn or refresh their memory on the Chi-square distribution and how the goodness of fit test works they can watch the Khan Academy videos on these topics. https://www.khanacademy.org/math/probability/statistics-inferential/chi-square/v/chi-square-distribution-introduction.

title: Scalable Battery Terminal Guard Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Protective cover for small 12V lead acid batteries - Project contains 3 battery sizes.

Printer:

Ordbot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print in PLA or ABS.

The OpenScad file is included to allow for customization.

The project was designed to provide an unobtrusive protective cover for lead acid battery terminals. This will prevent accidental short circuits or electrical shock. I have designed this for use with my other project, the Solar Charge Box, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:924112
.

The project is flexible. Edit the scad file and modify the "COVERSTYLE=x" variable to choose to:

  • print a full encapsulating guard
  • print a flat guard that sits on top of a battery.

.
Then edit the "OUTPUT=" variable to select your desired battery type/size.
The available sizes are:

  • 12V 12Ah battery
  • 12V 7 or 7.5 Ah battery
  • 12V 3.2 Ah battery

Use double sided tape to adhere the guard to the battery if necesary.

Battery Guard STL files have been precompiled and included for download:

  • 12 Ah full cover
  • 12 Ah flat top cover
  • 7 Ah full cover
  • 7 Ah flat top cover
  • 3.2 Ah full cover
  • 3.2A flat top cover

Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the white parts at 0.3 mm layer height and all the other parts at 0.2 mm.

description.text:
This Action Master style Skyfire is in response to a request by IsaacmusPrime for a Jetfire toy. This toy is larger than the standard Action Master in size.

I would suggest printing the head on its back with supports, the arms on their side with the post parts sticking up with supports, printing the backpack standing up on its jets with supports (not how I did on its back, it came out a bit ugly), the upper legs with the smaller hole side down and supports, the back jets on their sides with supports, pretty much everything should have supports. The body and back should snap together when finished (this was due to wanting to have the jetpack post go into the entire body). The leg accessories should be printed with the slot hole down. Superglue the leg accessories onto the legs. You will need two small screws to attach the upper legs to the waist (the kind that's used in a PC will work). I only printed two guns because I needed two objects that were the same height to get the barrels to come out correctly, so it's optional if you'd rather print something else as tall (like a sacrificial block).

Printer:

CTC

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2-0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed the white parts at 0.3 mm layer height and all the other parts at 0.2 mm.

comments.author: draco1

comments.text: Hi I'm friends with IsaacmusPrime if you have time cane you answer my question anout What stuff can the school buy for important stuff that cost $1'000 dollars that the school can buy. please do let me know that the school can get for $1'000 dollars please and thank you
comments.author: draco1

comments.text: Hi, it all depends on what you are trying to budget for. Is the $1000 the budget for the year for your 3D printing, or just how much you can spend on the printers? If I were buying printers now for a school I would suggest something like the XYZ junior (which I believe is enclosed) or Printrbot Simple Metal (not enclosed). Just know that your filament is going to be the biggest expense as 1kg is about $20+ each roll (I can sometimes find it cheaper on eBay, but the cheapest Chinese filament sometimes had quality problems like not measuring 1.75mm diameter and I have had rolls that had metal shavings in them which blocked up my extruder). Hope that helps.

In this activity students explore an incorrect statement about isosceles triangles that the scarecrow from The Wizard of Oz makes, seen here http://www.math.harvard.edu/~knill/mathmovies/swf/ozz.html. Then students explore right triangles with a related clip from The Simpsons, seen here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fO1Vhc88QkM. This leads to the Pythagorean Theorem. Students are shown an existing model and are asked to create their own. More detailed instructions are included in the Worksheet Solutions handout attached.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

I decided to use rectangles and split up the 3 by 3 square and left the 4 by 4 square to fit together to make the 5 by 5 square. I used Tinkercad to make all of these shapes separately. Your students may use different shapes, but it should be pretty easy to use the given geometric shapes or the shape generators.

Students get to act like real mathematicians as they decide if two conjectures are true and then try to prove or disprove them. All they need to know is the definitions of a right and isosceles triangle and some algebra. Objectives:
Students will see why these two conjectures are false and end up with the Pythagorean Theorem. They will then design a model to help show why the Theorem holds true. Skills Learned (Standards):
CCSS.Math.Content.8.G.B.6 - Explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse.

• First, students are given the property of triangles is that the sum of any two sides must be greater than the third side. They do a practice problem making sure they understand this.

  • Show the clip from The Wizard of Oz where the scarecrow says “the sum of the square roots of any two sides of an isosceles triangle is equal to the square root of the remaining side” and ask students if this is true then if it ever will be true.

  • Show the clip from The Simpsons where the triangle is said to be a right triangle and ask students if this statement is true.

  • Ask what the correct theorem is.

  • Show an existing 3D model that demonstrates the Pythagorean Theorem and ask students to design their own model.
Two days
Students should know the definitions of a right and isosceles triangle and know algebra.

Here is a sample rubric to use with the worksheet. Question (points)
1: (5)
2: (5)
3: (10)
4: (15)
5: (2)
6: (13) Total : 50

Some things you can review beforehand:
  • In an isosceles triangle two sides are equal.
  • In a triangle the side opposite the largest angle is the largest side.
  • Sides of a triangle have to be greater than 0.
Project: Exploring Triangles
An old tv.

comments.text: if you make top flat to  print it on a top - yes it will make your print easy, but at the same time it make this part fragile. Layer direction is crucial in this model. title: Rifle Controller for HTC Vive
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A rifle controller for use with the HTC Vive VR headset and room scale controllers. This Thing is based on remixes of several Things listed in the Remix Sources section below.

The Rifle Controller for HTC Vive has been tested with H3VR (http://h3vr.com/). Aside from the exceptions listed in the Known Issues section below, the rifle shoulder stock nearly perfectly aligns with the in-game rifle stocks. In order to use this controller properly, you must first grab the front of the in-game rifle just before placing the front controller into the controller holder. Once the rifle is held with two hands and controllers are in place, the rifle will align properly in the game and provide a steady, immersive, and more accurate in-game experience.

Due to CC licensing compatibility, the requires bolts/nuts and rifle stock parts are not included with this Thing. To obtain the other required parts:

Bolt & nut - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1696645
Rifle shoulder stock - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1696655

The fully assembled rifle controller requires 14 bolts and nuts.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Some parts will require supports from the bed.

If using full supports, or depending upon the accuracy of your printer calibration, you may need to file away some of the plastic in the bolt holes to allow for better alignment for the plastic bolts.

Assembly Considerations

Please be gentle when assembling as some parts may crack/break under stress if using too much force. When in doubt, file/sand where appropriate. I was able to fully assemble the rifle with only a small amount of filing to ease the insertion of the plastic bolts which are fragile.

Note that the bolts are not intended to "squeeze" components so take care not to over-torque. The printed bolts are intended to simply hold parts in place and add stability. If your print requires squeezing parts of the plastic, consider using metal bolts or plastic shims to provide stability.

Assembly Instructions
  1. Print each component that is part of this Thing.
  2. Print the shoulder stock Thing located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1696655
  3. Print 14 x nuts and bolts located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1696645
    Alternatively purchase metal bolts - 4.5Mx30mm bolts and 4.5M nuts
  4. Using the photos included with this Thing as a reference, assemble the parts using the plastic (or metal) bolts
  5. Optionally attach a strap to the strap holder loops found on the Stock Attachment and Front Barrel parts
  6. Load up H3VR, Out of Ammo, or your favorite Vive compatible shooter and achieve new high scores!
This part was remixed using Autodesk 123D Design

Nut & bolt - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647
Shoulder Stock - https://tinkercad.com/things/0arKMQnQear
Rifle controller components - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1642874

In H3VR, when using the Sako 85 you may need to remove the Vive remotes from the controller in order to reload. This is due to the rifle stock parts getting in the way.

Also with the Sako 85 you may find the rifle doesn't line up perfectly. It seems the bolt action rifle in H3VR has slightly different alignment than the M4A1, AK, etc.

title: Hex Base Adapters for MechWarrior Click Bases

description.text:
I do not recommend using these bases for anything other than bipedal 'mechs and infantry. The Hex size for the Quads and Vehicles are too big for good gameplay. I have taken to gluing the unbased 'mechs and vehicle mini's to 2 1/2 inch wide hexes that are 1/8 inch or 3 mm thick. N scale works great for Alpha Strike!

A few years back, Wiz Kids games published a very popular collectible miniatures game set in the BattleTech Universe. When the game went out of fashion, tons of miniatures were left behind. However, BattleTech and Alpha Strike need a hexagonal base for some of the rules.

These pieces will allow you to snap in your Mechwarrior: Dark Age and related figures without having to permanently change the base. However, if you want to glue your pieces in place, that will work, too.

The Vehicle Base is not right, the pocket is not wide enough for the bases.

STEAM Engine

Doesn't Matter

No

Anything

Notes:

Design Notes

I modeled this in Cubify Invent.

3D Printing is not the only way to make these parts: A Laser Cutter with 3/16 inch or 5 mm material will do well, too.

The top has a slight chamfer to make it easier to make a mold for producing lots of copies.

My sister designed this shield because of her constant bombardments of Nerf darts. I agreed to publish it and print it for her. This would also be useful for girls whose brothers pelt them with Nerf darts.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kq88mdMmvs6

This activity is for a Calculus class to help students visualize how to calculate volume by the shells method. Students will be given a typical volume problem and create 5 to 7 cylinder shells to approximate the shape. Then they make the actual shape and calculate the volume.

This is the companion activity to Finding Volume: Disc Method http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1711469

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

To create the rotated object and the cylinder shells I first got the 2 dimensional graph using desmos.com. Then I did a printscreen to capture the graph [figure 1]. I used an online SVG converter and opened it in 123d Design. I used the polyline tool to enclose the region [figure 2]. Then I used polyline again to draw a line acting as the y axis that this shape would get rotated over [Figure 3]. Next I drew rectangles at each interval point with a small width [Figure 4]. Then I used the revolve tool to rotate each rectangle around the line I drew [Figures 5 and 6]. To get the full object I revolved the whole graph around the line [Figure 7]. I also printed the object with a slice taken out so students can see the cross section. This was done by inserting a wedge and then subtracting it from the object [Figure 8].

Figure 1 Figure 2 Figure 3 Figure 4 Figure 5 Figure 6 Figure 7 Figure 8
NGSS CCSS

Project: Finding Volume: Shell Method Students understand how the shell method for finding volume works and create a model of both the approximation with shells and the actual 3D figure. Students will learn how to find the volume of a region using the shells method and why the formula works. These visuals will really help students see how the rotated 3d object ends up looking.

The full details are in the attached worksheet. Here is a brief overview. First assign each student (or group) a region that they will be rotating around the y-axis. Then have them use desmos.com, or a similar graph plotter, to plot their region. Then they will split the x values into 6-8 subintervals and create corresponding cylinder shells with radius x and height f(x). Next, they will think about the full region rotated and print that. Then they will get the formula for surface area of a cylinder and volume of the rotated region. Finally, they will calculate the volume for their region.

• Volume of a Region
  • cylinder shells
The activity itself can be completed in one day but printing the rotated object will take a couple hours.

This activity should be done at the point in calculus when students first learn how to find volume by shells. They probably have already done volume by discs and have all of the pre-requisite knowledge, such as knowing how to evaluate integrals. You might need to remind them of the equation for circumference of a circle.

Here is a sample rubric to use with the worksheet.
Question (points)
1 (2)
2 (2)
3 (10)
4 (20)
5 (5)
6 (11) Total 50

It could be helpful to give a quick review of Riemann sums or have students watch a video on the topic. https://www.khanacademy.org/math/integral-calculus/indefinite-definite-integrals/riemann-sums/v/simple-riemann-approximation-using-rectangles.

Incense will draw in nearby Pokémon by emitting a mysterious fragrance.

Incense is an item in Pokémon GO that, upon activation, draws wild Pokémon towards the player at an accelerated rate for thirty minutes in real time. The player starts the game with two of them in their inventory, and can obtain more upon leveling up or by purchasing them with PokéCoins at the in-app store. The item spawns approximately one Pokémon every five minutes if standing still, or one Pokémon every minute if walking.

title: Roomba 500Series Side brush gear
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After 48 month of every-day hard work my side brush decided not to turn anymore. After analysing the issue it turned out the middle gear of my side brush module missed the regular checkup at the dentist and hence lost some teeth...

Since I do not like to cleanup myself I decided to open Blender and design new gears. Here we go! 15 Minutes later my Roomba was as good as new.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,16

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Strong recommendation to print in nylon for increased durability

It required to re-drill the hole with a 2.1mm driller
Minor sanding on the lower side was required in order to smoothen the edges.
In Blender I generated two gears with 10 and 42 teeth respectively.

comments.text: I ordered this from Shapeways in HP nylon plastic and my Roomba stripped the small gears immediately, so I'd recommend a stronger material. I'm trying again with stainless steel. The shape and size seemed to perfectly match the stock Roomba part though, so nice work on the model!

I've always wanted an articulated Gremlin and decided to try making one,
this is it.

Gremlin STL
by Hoinz
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:258879

and I used these joint connectors from

http://www.toyforge.in/products/test-print-kit

and included alternate head and hands files (non articulated ears and fingers)
that should be be easier and faster to print at layer 0.2mm
Use supports when printing,

joints need proper clean sanding to snap together

description.text: Our SodaStream fell down and the part that pushes the CO2 valve broke. So.. I have a 3d printer, why not make another one! After a few iterations and remeasures (yay digital calipers), this one finally worked!

Notes:

The 20% infill one ended up separating, I made a new one (v2) and printed it at 100% infill. More solid!
Measured from the original part, created in Tinkercad

I recently posted openSCAD polyhedron files for the Johnson solids, thing:16508, based on information in the polyhedra libary at netlib.
http://netlib.sandia.gov/polyhedra/ The netlib library contains additional polyhedra. Using the same fortran program I converted the netlib files for the prisms, antiprisms, and Platonic solids to openSCAD polyhedron commands, then to stl files, and printed them. See the images at the left. The models were scaled to a maximum dimension of about 50 mm to make a uniform set. I was pleased at how rapidly they printed and how well the flat surfaces at the tops of some of the models were filled in. The Platonic solids have been done many times before but they came out so well that I have included them here. These convex polyhedra were made hollow by scaling a copy to make it smaller and subtracting away the unwanted material in openSCAD. A scale factor of 0.9 was used; leaving enough material for a sturdy model. All of the hollow polyhedra stl files are included in hollow_stl.zip and the scad files that produced them are in hollow_scad.zip. Prisms included are: triangular, pentagonal, hexagonal, octagonal, and decagonal; antiprisms are: square, pentagonal, hexagonal, octagonal, and decagonal; Platonic solids are: tetrahedron, cube, octahedron, dodecahedron, and icosahedron. A module containing the polyhedon command that produces the polyhedra is at the end of each scad file and can be extracted and used in other openSCAD programs. Separate stl files for the tetrahedron, dodecahedron, square antiprism, pentagonal prism, and pentagonal antiprism are included below. The excellent site, "Virtual Polyhedra" by George Hart has more information, see
http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/vp.html

The files were printed on a Thing-O-Matic using a heated surface covered with Kapton tape.  The surface was cleaned with acetone before each print and the models adhered well to the surface.  A raft was used although it may not be necessary if your build platform is well leveled.
As an example the tetrahedron pictured has edges of 59 mm.  It took about 50 minutes to print.  The finished print weighs 6 grams and has a volume of 24 cubic centimeters.  It is light and sturdy.

description.text: Made this little dude with 123D Design.

A simple jig for drilling the mounting holes for the Flitetest Electrohub and fits 1/2 inch wooden dowels. The unmarked hole in the end should be drilled through regardless of the configuration of the copter. The X holes are for an X configuration quad (should work with hexacopters or octocopters as well) and the S hole is for a spider configuration quad (AKA dead cat quad). It makes consistent, precise drilling much easier and lends to a nicer overall build.

Update: The jig was just a little too long from the end to the first hole. This has been corrected to the ~6mm recommended by flitetest. The original version of this jig was 1-2mm too long for the spider quad booms.

author: KOYOMATSUI

description.text:
Tried numerous ball sockets and have been disappointed with their ability to retain the ball under stress. You may want to start off just printing two to make sure your print settings are configured to prevent the posts from snapping. You want a light fill, 10 - 15%, to keep the flexibility of the material. The balls were designed to have the maximum level of friction with the socket, and to be able to withstand several pounds of weight before disengaging. They can also be printed with two teeth taken out for 90 degree bends (less grabbing power).

Default size is 33mm's tall, and 18.5mm's wide. The ball is 13mm.

Nylon would be the best material to print with, but most materials will work with the right print settings. If the ball-ends aren't providing enough holding power as a result of wear, they can be lightly sprayed with a hard coating, like polyurethane, to provide better friction. They also make great pawns :) If you have a project that requires a lot of holding power, you'll have to increase the scale- as more size = more surface area = more holding power...

author: PurelyNicole

print_settings.Notes:: hb.stl

description.text:
Students learn the most when they are having fun, so that is why I made Ed Blocks. Ed Blocks inspire students of all ages by providing hands-on learning.

Part of the design of the blocks requires the student to problem solve the placement and pairing of the blocks unique interlocking slide system. The slide system is specifically designed to challenge student's problem solving skills. It also provides multiple connection options with both interlocking slides and peg and hole placement options. This allows for both horizontal and vertical connection points enhancing students creativity and building capabilities. There are also two and four way connectors and octagon beams and holes to allow for varying angles of connection.

Tools like this can make a big deference in a student's development of spatial awareness, creativity, problem solving and design. Worksheets don't inspire student's creativity, but when a student is having fun and engaged in kinesthetic learning they get inspired to do great things. Simple building blocks were the impetus for my creativity and love for designing. That is why I want to inspire student's all around the world with Ed Blocks and hope that they will do the same.

Are you wondering what all the file names mean? Here is what they mean:

h.stl - Horizontal block
hh.stl - Horizontal block with hole
hb.stl - Horizontal block with beam
hhb.stl - Horizontal block with hole and beam
h2.stl - Horizontal two way connecter block
h2h - Horizontal two way connecter block with hole
h2b - Horizontal two way connecter block with
h2hb.stl - Horizontal two way connecter block with hole and beam
h4.stl - Horizontal four way connecter
h4h.stl - Horizontal four way connecter with hole
h4b.stl - Horizontal four way connecter with beam
h4hb.stl - Horizontal four way connecter with hole and beam

If you have any questions comments or concerns please let me know.

Coming up next:

  • 3 way connector

Please note that I still have school so I will work on those whenever I can.

https://youtu.be/1Xnl7mXM2GE

Printer:

da Vinci Jr. 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Standard 0.2 mm (200 microns)

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Supports only needed for

  • hb.stl
  • hhb.stl
  • h2b
  • h2hb.stl,
  • h4b.stl,
  • h4hb.stl

Ed Blocks Desnigning Prosses

I spent my whole summer vacation working on the Ed Blocks. I spent over one hour every day for about 90 days.

Using SketchUp 2016 I went though twenty-three different designs to get the Ed Blocks perfect. I started with a block that was 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) long and 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) wide and I knew that was to big. So then I shrunk it down to about 1.75 inches (4.445 centimeters) long and 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) wide. My final height for the Ed Blocks is 0.5996063 inches tall (1.523 centimeters) tall.

I went though about 160 meter of filament for all of my previous designs. As you can see in some of the pictures above that I have only four green blocks. That is because I was only able to print four of my final designs in green because the rest of my filament went to all of my trial and error blocks. Luckily I had another spool of clear blue filament to print the rest of my blocks.

The hardest part of designing these blocks was to make sure that the grooves fit into each other. If they were off by .3 millimeters then they would not fit. The first couple designs that I made did not have any grooves at all. The problem with that is there was no mechanism to hold them together.

When I was building with the blocks I found that I needed a block that could make a creation taller. I then created blocks with square beams and other blocks with matching square holes. Just like the grooves, if it was just a little bit off it would not fit. It took about four days to perfect.

After completing the beam and hole blocks, I wanted to challenge myself to develop a block you could position at different angles. I accomplished this by changing the square beams and holes to octagons. The blocks with octagon beams and holes allowed the blocks to be positioned at different angles. The difficulty in working with octagons was aligning the center and ensuring all the sides were equavalent. Thankfully SketchUp had a tool that I could make a octagon out of.

Just like any other building block you don't want to be stuck building in one direction, so I designed two way connectors and four way connectors. I designed the two way connector and the four way connector by copying parts of the hh.stl block and then attaching them onto a cube. After I attached the grooves to the block, I had to clean it up by taking out the unnecessary lines caused by copying and pasting in Sketchup .

Once I made the original blocks I copied and pasted them three times to add one with a hole, one with a beam, and one with both.

Top of the Ed Blocks in SketchUp

I started with my original block and then added a beam. I then copied the beam onto both my two way and four way connector blocks. The beams have to be perfectly centered or else the bottom block will not line up with the top block. Some beams were easier to put on than others. If you look at the image bellow or the file image above you can see that the four way connector is not a rectangle nor square, so I had to fill it in a make it a rectangle so the lines would be centered. Then I had to delete what I filled in.

Bottom of the Ed Blocks in SketchUp Tips

I recommend that you copy and paste your original block to use when designing your beams, two way and four way connector blocks.

Additionally, when I was printing my first block with a beam, I found that it is easier to print with the beam facing down. That is due to the fact that if you put the beam facing up the supports print into the interlocking grooves making it difficult to take out. Even though it will take longer to print, it will be easier to take the supports off. It is completely up to you to decide what way you want to face it, but I recommend printing with the beam facing down.

Project Name

I gave my blocks the name Ed Blocks. They enhance creativity, problem solving, spatial awareness, designing and construction. Most of all they are fun and inspiring learning tools.

Overview & Background

The Ed Blocks will give teachers all around the world an opportunity to let their students have fun while learning. The Ed blocks will help students learn the skill of problem solving, planning, construction, design and spatial awareness. Using Ed Blocks students can imagine possibilities and see them to reality. With these blocks you find a challenge and then find a way to overcome that challenge. Teachers and students can also make numbers and letters out of the blocks. This is a great kinesthetic way for students to learn their numbers and letters. Students can also learn patterns and counting. The blocks can be printed in deferent colors and then lined up in a pattern and the students can try to guess what the pattern is. Counting can also be added in by stacking or lining the blocks up and then counting them. The educational opportunities are as endless as our imagination.

Objectives

The objective of Ed Blocks is a fun and engaging learning tool. Students should be expected to learn the meaning and skill of problem solving, number counting and being familiar with numbers, patterns, letters and designing. Ed Blocks also enhance creativity, building, design and spatial awareness. Most of all the objective for Ed Blocks is to have fun!

Audiences

Ed Blocks are fun, engaging and educational for people of all ages. They can be used in elementary schools for kinesthetic learning and adapted for lessons on colors, patterns, shapes, numbers and letters.

Subjects

The Ed Blocks can be used in:

  • Math
  • Language Arts
  • General Education
Skills Learned (Standards)

Students should have a broad understanding of skills of designing, creativity, and problem solving and spatial awareness.

Lesson/Activity

The Ed Blocks can be used for many different lessons or activity's.

The teacher can pull up a image on a projector or verbally say what he or she wants the students to build. This can be done individually and the can learn the skill of problem solving, or they can work as a team of three to four and learn the skills of teamwork and problem solving as a team.

With younger grades the teacher can build a pattern and then ask the students what the pattern is, or the teacher can tell the student to build a pattern like red and blue. The patterns do not have to be color the can be something like beam and no beam, or two way connector and four way connector.

With younger grades the teacher can use these blocks to create letters to help teach the students their letters. After watching the teacher build, he/she can ask the students to build their own letters. When kids get into words then the teacher can ask the student to build a word the a teacher say to build or for them just to build their own words

With younger grades the teacher can use these blocks to create numbers to help teach the kids their numbers. After the teacher so the kids the letters than he/she can ask the students to build their own numbers. When kids get into math problems then the teacher can ask the student to build a math problem and then answer it or to build their own math problem and answer it.

Ed Blocks can also be used to build creatively. Students can be asked to design and build a creation that inspires them. This can be used during class time or during an indoor recess.

Have Fun!

Duration

Lessons with Ed Blocks can be as short or long as you would like.

Preparation

Blocks would need to be printed prior to the lesson time. Block printing takes 1.45 hours for a standard block. Instruction would also need to be given on how to use the blocks.

References

No references needed to create Ed Blocks.

Rubric & Assessment

Students should be assessed on their creativity and problem solving in using Ed Blocks.

Handouts & Assets

No handouts or assets needed to have an awesome time with the Ed Blocks.

title: Ballistic Pendulum (To Measure Speed of NERF Dart)

description.text:
This is a ballistic pendulum. It is constructed of 3D printed parts, 1/4" wooden dowels, and string. Its purpose is to measure the speed of NERF darts and other small, low speed projectiles. This is a MakerEd Challenge 2.0 entry.

To use: Shoot a dart at the pendulum. Measure how high it swings. Calculate the gravitational potential energy from "mgh". Use that to calculate the kinetic energy of the dart, "KE", which is 0.5mv^2. Solve for v to get the speed. See handouts for more information.

Test of the prototype: https://youtu.be/BXyvUQC2mLQ
The connectors were designed in TinkerCAD. The bolt and threaded hole were made using mike_linus' "NUT JOB" customizer. The rest of this was designed using 123D design from AutoDesk.

description.header: Project: Ballistic Pendulum (To Measure Speed of NERF Dart)
description.text:
Project Name

Ballistic Pendulum (To Measure Speed of NERF Dart)

Overview & Background

Students will learn how to use physics and math (and optionally engineering) to measure the speed of a NERF dart.

Objective

By completing this project, students will learn about kinetic energy and potential energy. They will also learn how to calculate mean, median, mode, and standard deviation. There are engineering / design exercises that are optional as well.

Audiences

This project is suitable for anyone learning physics, math, or engineering. It is also a fun way to introduce kids to STEM. Anyone who likes NERF guns should also enjoy the project.

Skills Learned / Standards

The skills learned in this project include: setting up and performing an experiment; calculating statistics; and basic engineering / design skills.

Lesson / Activity

After the ballistic pendulum is assembled, students will come up with a way to measure how high the coin box will swing. Then they will fire a dart at it. Once they have obtained the height, they can calculate the velocity of the dart.

The coin box can be loaded with coins to make it heavier if it swings too high when empty. Or if it doesn't swing high enough to measure easily, the lid and bolt can be removed. Cardboard or Velcro can be used to make the darts stick to the box.

See handouts for more information.

Duration

About one hour or less.

Preparation

Students should know some basic math and a little bit of physics. They will also need a dart gun and darts, as well as some way to measure the height of the swinging coin box (a ruler, graph paper, a marker, a smartphone, etc.). A piece of cardboard with tape inserted into one of the slots on the coin box will make suction cups stick to the box. A small piece of Velcro will make Velcro darts stick. A calculator (or smartphone calculator app) is necessary to carry out the math.

References

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ballistic_pendulum
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_deviation

Rubric & Assessment

By the end of this project, students should have assembled a ballistic pendulum. They should have taken ten height measurements and calculated ten velocities. They should have completed the calculations handouts, which includes calculating the mean, median, mode, and standard deviation. They should also have done some critical thinking about the experiment.

Handouts

Handout 1: Instructions.
Handout 2: Discussion.
Handout 3: Calculations.

Love the Makies Pumpkin! - printed a few and then made some tweaks (this community is filled with people who can't leave well enough alone!)
  • Separated the pumpkin top and the stem into 2 separate pieces so you can print in different colors more easily.
    1a. Added threads so stem screws into the pumpkin top.
  • Added an inner lip to the top so it fits atop the pumpkin more steadily.
  • Sized all pieces UP to accommodate standard tea light - I recommend using the lil battery powered ones for safety.
  • Added a 40mm divot to accept the base of tea light.

Printed easily using PLA on a Rep2 and and Rep2x - Med setting in Makerware.  I know it appears odd but I rotated the pumpkin so the "zipper" (where the print starts and stops) will be at the rear of the pumpkin. My Rep2x has a "zipper" issue on some prints.

description.text: Project Prostheducate was created to bring prosthetics and 3D modeling into the classroom. It gives students the chance to design and 3D print their own prosthetic attachments. Students will develop engineering skills, 3D modeling skills, and problem solving skills while participating in Project Prostheducate. This project is an easy and affordable way to introduce students to the world of 3D printing and 3D modeling.

Printer Brand:

Notes:

The Project Prostheducate Prosthetic was printed on a Printrbot Play. Since it was not an option for "Printer Model", I selected "Simple White" because the Printrbot Simple is very similar to the Printrbot Play. Rafts and supports are not needed to print the Project Prostheducate Prosthetic.|

I designed the Project Prostheducate Prosthetic and its attachments  with its simplicity in mind. I wanted to keep things simple and easy to understand, while maintaining complete functionality. I used 123D Design to create the Project Prostheducate Prosthetic. To make the prosthetic a reality, I first started with sketches of the attachments and the prosthetic. Then I began to design everything using basic shapes and simple measurements. After several prototypes, I was able to create working attachments for the Project Prostheducate prosthetic.

Project Name 
 Project Prostheducate is an appropriate name for this project because the project was created to educate students about prosthetics and their impact on the lives of amputees.
Overview and Background 
 Project Prostheducate was created as an easy and affordable way to bring prosthetics into the classroom. Students participating in Project Prostheducate have the opportunity to design and 3D print their own attachments to add on to the prosthetic. Students are introduced to the world of 3D modeling and 3D printing, while developing problem solving skills. Project Prostheducate is ideal for students in grades three through ten because of its easy-to-understand concept, yet challenging curriculum. Students participating in Project Prostheducate will have lots of fun while creating prosthetic attachments for the Project Prostheducate prosthetic.
Objectives

By the end of Project Prostheducate, students would be expected to have learned:

  1. How to design 3D models
  2. How a 3D printer works
  3. How important hands are in everyday tasks
  4. How to turn sketches and measurements into a physical object
Audiences 
 Project Prostheducate is perfect for students in grades three through ten. This project is basic enough for younger students to comprehend, yet complex enough to challenge older students. The lesson plans created by the teachers should be based off of their students’ ages and skill levels.
Subjects 
 Project Prostheducate would be a great learning experience for students in math or science class. Math or science would be the ideal subjects for this project because it teaches kids engineering skills, which help students use and strengthen their math and science skills.
Skills Learned 
 The students participating in Project Prostheducate would gain engineering skills, 3D modeling skills, and problem solving skills.
Lesson/Activity

How to participate in Project Prostheducate:

  1. To begin Project Prostheducate, review the resources found on the Project Prostheducate Thingiverse page. These resources will help prepare you for designing and 3D printing your own attachments. The resources will also help you understand how 3D printing works.

  2. Once you have completed Step 1, go to the Project Prostheducate Thingiverse Page and download all of the files. Print each file as many times as follows:
    Attachment Base- 1
    Wrist- 1
    Long Hinge Pins- 2
    Computer Keyboard Typing Attachment- 1
    iPhone Holder- 1
    Pencil Holder- 1
    Shoe Tying Helper- 1
    Snack Cup Holder- 1
    Spoon and Fork Holder- 1
    Toothbrush Holder- 1
    Violin Bow Holder- 1

  3. Assemble the Project Prostheducate Prosthetic using the instructions below.
    A. Once you have printed every part of the prosthetic, you can start assembling. Lay everything out on a flat surface so it is easy to find the parts.assembling. Lay everything out on a flat surface so it is easy to find the parts.

                B. The first thing you will assemble is the wrist. The wrist part of the prosthetic comes in two sections so it can fit on smaller printers. Glue the two pieces together using super glue or hot glue. The pieces should fit perfectly together. Then, use pliers or other tools to remove the six support structures. There are gaps in the wrist for Velcro straps. Using Velcro is optional. The Velcro should go through the top gap and out through the other top. Then down through the one bottom one and out the other end. The Velcro straps are used to secure the amputee's wrist to the prosthetic.

            C. Now that the wrist is assembled, you can start assembling the prosthetic. Grab the wrist, attachment base, and the two hinge pins included in the wrist file. Then, line up the holes on the wrist and attachment base. Insert the two hinge pins into the holes. This secures the wrist and attachment base together.

            D. The prosthetic is now complete, but the attachments still need to be assembled. See Step 5 for individual instructions on each attachment. To insert an attachment into the Project Prostheducate Prosthetic, you will need the two long hinge pins, the prosthetic, and an attachment. Insert the attachment into the prosthetic at the front. The holes will automatically line up as long as the attachment is fully inserted. Push the two long hinge pins all the way into the wrist through the holes. This secures the attachment to the prosthetic. This process works for every attachment. You can now use the prosthetic and its attachment.

            E. Individual Instructions on Each Attachment:

    Computer Keyboard Typing Attachment- This attachment does not need to be assembled.
    iPhone Holder- To assemble the iphone holder, you need all of the parts included in the iPhone Holder file found on the Project Prostheducate Thingiverse Page. (See the pictures below for the names of the parts.) Line up the holes on the arm and the stand, then insert the hinge pins into the holes. This secures the arm and the stand together. The iPhone Holder is designed to fit both the iPhone 6 and the iPhone 6 Plus. Look at the pictures below for instructions on how to change the attachment to fit the different iPhones.
    Pencil Holder- This attachment does not need to be assembled, but it requires a rubber band. In order for the pencil not to slide through the attachment, you need to wrap a rubber band around it. The height at which you wrap it is up to you. Push the pencil through the attachment until it doesn’t fall out when turned upside down. The attachment can also hold pens, some highlighters, and some markers.
    Shoe Tying Helper- This attachment does not need to be assembled.
    Spoon and Fork Holder- This attachment does not need to be assembled, but it requires a rubber band. In order for the spoon or fork to stay in the attachment and not fall out, it needs to be secured with a rubber band. The rubber band should be wrapped around the pegs sticking out of the attachment.
    Snack Cup Holder- To assemble the Snack Cup Holder, you will need super glue/hot glue. Glue the bottom of the holder part of the attachment to the insert part of the attachment.
    Toothbrush Holder- To assemble the Toothbrush Holder, you will need super glue or hot glue. Make sure you have all of the parts from the Toothbrush Holder file. Take the slider part and stick it through the base part. Glue the plate part onto the bottom of the slider part. This secures the Slider to the Base, while still allowing it to move around. To secure the toothbrush in the holder, use a rubber band. Wrap the rubber band around the pegs and around the Plate Part on the bottom of the holder. (See pictures for help with rubber band.)
    Violin Bow Holder- To assemble the Violin Bow Holder, glue the Bow Holder part to the insert part. Make sure the skinnier pegs are on the sides and the thicker pegs are on the top and bottom. (See pictures for help with this.) You can add a rubber band to secure the violin bow in the holder.

  4. Once you have printed and assembled the Project Prostheducate Prosthetic, your next task is to play around with it! Study how it works and try to understand how it was designed.

  5. If you understand how the prosthetic works and how it was designed, you are ready to start designing your own prosthetic attachment. Design your attachment on 123d Design. Import the Attachment Insert file into a new design plane in 123d Design. Then, create your attachment coming off of that model. Be patient, you will go through many prototypes before finalizing your prosthetic attachment.

  6. Once you have designed an attachment, you can download that file and 3D print it. If your attachment doesn’t work like it should, just keep trying. You will succeed eventually.

  7. When your attachment is perfect and doesn’t need any editing, you are then ready to upload your attachment. You will need a Thingiverse account for this, so make an account if you don’t have one. Log in to your Thingiverse account and upload your attachment to the “Made” section of the Project Prostheducate Thingiverse page. We would love to see the wonderful and useful attachments you create!
Examples of prototypes for the Project Prostheducate Prosthetic The two wrist pieces should fit perfectly together. Labeled parts for the Wrist and Attachment Base. Labeled parts for the prosthetic and attachment. Labeled parts for the iPhone Holder Attachment. Two Hinge Pins are in the Arm. This setting is the iPhone 6 setting. One Hinge Pin is in the Arm. This setting is the iPhone 6 Plus setting. The rubber band is wrapped around the pencil so the pencil does not slip through the attachment. The rubber band is wrapped around the Spoon/Fork Holder Attachment so the spoon does not fall out when tipped upside down. The Snack Cup Holder is printed in two parts. Those parts are glued together like the picture above shows. The Violin Bow Holder Attachment is printed in two parts. The parts are glued as shown in the picture above. The rubber band is wrapped around the Toothbrush Holder Attachment so the toothbrush won't fall out. Duration 
 Project Prostheducate should take approximately 2-4 weeks to complete. It could take longer if the students and the teacher continue to make attachments past the four week mark.
Preparation 
 Before beginning Project Prostheducate, students should make sure they have access to a 3D printer and a computer. Students don’t need to know anything about 3D printers or 3D modeling before beginning this project. Project Prostheducate gives students an opportunity to develop and strengthen their 3D modeling skills and to learn how 3D printing works.
        Materials/Technologies needed for Project Prostheuducate:
                          1. 3D printer/s
                          2. Computer/s
                          3. 3D printing filament
                          4. Rubber bands
                          5. Super glue/ hot glue (Teacher’s choice)
                          6. 7/8" Velcro Straps (Optional)
                          7. Pliers or other tools for removing support structures
References
  1. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZVGXcqVHCaw
    Creating Basic Objects
  2. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bdrm47ZWkBA
    Moving and Snapping
  3. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3VwUSOrNSEA
    Grouping Objects
  4. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P7vbOcASm6c
    Edges, Faces, and Points
  5. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lc-JCJ82UxI
    Adding, Subtracting, and Intersecting Objects
  6. http://cdn.123dapp.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/123d-design-manual.pdf
    123d Design Manual
  7. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vx0Z6LplaMU
    What is 3D Printing and How Does it Work?
  8. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Llgko_GpXbI
    What is 3D Printing and How Does it Work? (Cartoon Version)
  9. http://3dprinting.com/what-is-3d-printing/
    Information on 3D Printing
Rubric and Assessment 
 By the end of the project, the class should have printed the Project Prostheducate Prosthetic, printed at least three of the attachments, and each student should have attempted to design their own attachment. The achievements expected from the students should be based off of their ages and skill levels. A 10th grader should be expected to accomplish greater tasks than a 3rd grader. How the students are graded is entirely up to the teacher.
Handouts and Assets

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1F__JwDFBgi8031ftAiLsbvGhqGToETzN9xkL2EB_btA/edit?usp=sharing
Design Your Own Attachment Worksheet

I didn't know how to make a smart file when I originally made it, so just a linear scale should do the trick.
It was made for a 10.5 (20.2 mm). If you want to get a ring size x, what scaling factor (percentage) do you need?
the proportion is x/20.2 = y/100, so y = 4.95x.
9.5 - 19.4mm - 96%
10 - 18.8mm - 92.1%

title: Two Blue Laser Diode Beam Combiner

description.text:
I am working on a two Blue Laser Diode beam combiner. It will be made of 6061 T6 Aluminum. This will use two Laser host modules with lens to hold the Diodes (top and front facing bored 12mm holes). Another partial module will be drilled out and used to hold the output lens at the bottom 12mm bored hole. These bores must be on the same plane and the same axis. The Diode lenses will be focused to infinity into the combining cube. Those cubes are wavelength specific and are 12.7mm square. that goes into the well in the side of the housing. The housing has been "heat sinked". There will be two 30mm X 10mm fans installed above each Laser module (not shown).

Height 57.5mm
width 33mm*
length 47.5mm

This design is for using two less expensive Laser Diodes rather than one more expensive diode. It also will add flexibility as one or both Lasers can be used depending on the job material or type.

This design is for the inexpensive "Benbox" style DIY Laser kits.

This is a work in progress.

Beam combiner5.stl is the new version with fan mounts added in. The heat sink fins on the horizontal Diode extension had to be turned 90deg. The fan would not fit on top.

Beam Combiner cube:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Laser-Beam-Combine-Cube-Prism-Mirror-for-405nm-450nm-2W-445nm-Blue-Laser-Diode-/331101469581?hash=item4d172f7b8d:g:t3EAAOxyOlhSyoSv

Diode Hosts:
https://sites.google.com/site/dtrlpf/home/diode-modules/12mm-copper-modules

Edited size of object. Increased cooling area. Dimensions changed 8/10/16
I used Sketchup 2016 to design this Laser housing

description.text: Fan mount for 40mm fan with duct, Prusa v1 x carriage.  This duct cools the workpiece.

DISCLAIMER: This will probably not work on your printer due to hotend length.  It is designed for a J-head mk4 B, prusa v1 carriage with brass bushings.  Nominal bed clearance at Z=0 is 2mm.
Because this is a contracting duct, it puts back-pressure on the fan.  If the tip clearances are too large the fan will stall and move very little air.  It is possible to fix this by stuffing little slips of paper into the gap between the blade ends and the fan housing.
This was designed in solidworks, so there is no openscad file.  Please do not ask for one.
The .sldprt file may have some changes that did not make it into the .stl file.  I was going to print a second version but never finished it.  Also, the orientation it's built in is wrong.  You'll have to make an assembly and align the part to the planes so that the duct points up in positive Z.  In this orientation it prints very nicely.
The duct mounts to the underside of the belt clamps.  Minimum screw length is something around 15 or 20mm.  You can either leave the belt clamp nuts in their traps and add 2 more nuts to hold the duct on, or use the original nuts to hold everything in place.  There are not nut traps on the duct (because in my experience 3mm nut traps are very weak), so you may need to hold the nuts still with small pliers while you torque the screws down.
The top hole spacing is designed to match the belt clamps on the stock Prusa X carriage.  If you are using a different X carriage I recommend checking your belt clamp spacing before printing.
If I remember correctly the fan hole spacing is 32mm.
I used slic3r to slice this file, and ran into the thin wall bug about 90% of the way through the print.  Fortunately, all this does is slightly shorten the duct, so the part is still usable.

title: Wing ribs with swept leading edge

description.text:
Set of wing ribs as part of the internal structure for a wing with a swept leading edge and some other interesting features. They are made with the intent of mounting on wood or composite rods to frame out a wing.

Right now this is a very early stage. I hope to get the detail level up to that of the generic wing rib I made that could form a straight wing. Just takes some time to get it nice in Blender.

Even when finished, this will need further adjustment. I don't have my own 3D printing gear, so you're going to need to do various checks and determine a usable scale before you try making it.

----[ Update 8/3/16 ]----
All the ribs should now have the holes for the supporting rods to pass though. The wingtip pieces are a little different, as instead of the I-beam like section they're closed on the outside face. (Intended to cap off the wing.) Other pieces will still need cleanup, but I'm sure when compared to the previous versions of the file - you may be able to see what direction it's going in terms of improved shape definition.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/r8hS5w9PxI0" ></iframe>
Process of modeling in Blender along with a few thoughts on the underlying design.

title: Wonky Drawers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Looks like my design of a set of drawers went a bit 'wonky'...

In a world where most things are designed to be symmetrical and follow conventional lines it's sometimes fun to break away with something truly unique and completely different.... but that still provides a practical / functional solution.

'Wonky Drawers' do just that...

Wonky Drawers look very cool... most people's immediate reaction is "I want one of those" . so they will make a great gift.

Apart from looking 'different' they are still a practical set of drawers for small things. Each of the five drawers are different sizes and shapes however they all have a depth of 44mm (inside front to back). They provide a reasonable amount of storage space so can be used for small parts, toys, jewellery hobby/craft things and much more... plus they are fun and decorative so can easily become a conversation starter.

'Wonky Drawers' are easy to print but do take time due to the size. At standard scale the frame measures approx. 76mm (W) x 165mm (H) x 50mm (D). The back of the frame has been left open to reduce print time and filament consumption however this also means the drawers can be pushed out from behind if necessary. There are also designed in drawer stops across the rear top edge of edge drawer slot so the drawers won't push through and out the back.

Each of the drawers has a small handle that has been designed to print in PLA without support on machines with a filament fan (i.e. The angle should be printable fro most machines). The handles have a recess/hollow inside and are wide enough to make them easily hooked by a finger nail and the drawers should slide open with minimal effort as the drawer to frame clearances clearances have been set to make sure they should slide well regardless of the type of machine they are printed on (...as all machines / slicing apps print differently)

Because 'Wonky Drawers' are a bit quirky have fun with colors if you have a range of filament available... but if not they still look great with the frame one colour and drawers all in a second color.

Print 'Wobbly Drawers' for yourself or great as a unique gift/s. Please post images of your prints for other users to see them in use and see the color variations out there.

Please refer to the print settings information and images for additional information..

Note: If you like 'Wonky Drawers' take a look at the rest of my practical and fun designs!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard 0.20mm

Infill:

2 shells / 20% infill / PLA

Notes:

Easy prints without support. The back of the frame has been left hollow to reduce filament consumption. Small drawer stop strips have been designed in at the top of each drawer slot so they can't slide out the back.

Just slide your drawers into you farme and you have 'Wonky Drawers'

Great for small parts, toys, jewellery, stationery items and more...fill up your Wonky Drawers and, as it makes a great display piece as well as providing practical storage for small things, put it on display where everyone can see it!.

title: Nema 17 Stepper motor mounts for Delta Printer

description.text:
Building a popular delta 3d printer from some plans, and needed a better way to attach the steppers. People are using zip ties but I wanted something stronger and easily removable. I also had an issue with lateral play because of the nature of this build and the materials I used (MDF and metal rods.) By adding the four machine screws with the mounts I noticed a huge difference and any lateral racking and twisting was eliminated. Print faceplate down for best results.

The Nema 17 Steppers use a M3 size, 8mm length(any longer and they will bottom out), and 5mm pitch
Also used #10 machine screw for mounting to the printer

description.text:
A great way to keep your Pebble Time out of the way while it's charging.

Attach a stock charging cable with a "tape donut" so it molds around the end of the cable, sticking all 3 sides to the mount. Or, use hot glue if you want a more permanent fit.

You can screw the mount to the wall if you wish, or use trimmed 3M adhesive strips, or magnets if you have something metal nearby, etc.

remixed_from.author: 3DCentralVA
remixed_from.title: Articulated Jellyfish! Ball-joint articulated octopus Remix!

description.text:
Sometimes you see a model on thingiverse and just have to put a light (or lights) in it. That was the case with this one. The first time I saw it, I immediately downloaded it, hollowed out the dome and middle sections of the jellyfish, scaled them up as big as I could print them on my trusty printrbot, and started printing. I finished printing and jellyfish assembly on Saturday but have to wait a few more days for the electronics to arrive.

It's about 13 inches tall, and there's a video at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M_Wk8TVNJt8

The bottom and tentacles can be found on the original page. All I did was scale them up 1.8x (I think I scaled the tentacle end up more, maybe 2.6x - print one and see if it fits before you print the rest). In fact, print one of each of the ball-joint connecting ones first and test for fit before you print everything. I had to make some minor size tweaks to get them to work on my printer.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10

Physical assembly:
  • Snap the ball joints together in the obvious fashion.
  • I used a hot-air gun to thermal weld the middle section to the bottom section once all the tentacles were attached. I also welded on the center mast (to hold the electronics) and the latches. Still working on getting the latches just right.
  • I used a hot-air gun and a set of pliers to punch holes for the charging port on the adafruit powerboost 500C and my button.
Electronics

In this build, I'm using:
Adafruit Neopixel ring - 12x5050 RGB - https://www.adafruit.com/products/1643
Adafruit PowerBoost 500 Charger - https://www.adafruit.com/products/1944
Generic 1000mAh LiPo - http://www.ebay.com/itm/361366607971
An arduino nano that I picked up for a couple bucks from Aliexpress - any arduino that will fit should work fine for this.
Generic pushbutton
A bunch of wires

See the breadboard picture for my circuit.

I'm monitoring the battery voltage and flashing a warning, then shutting down if the battery gets too low.

I also destroyed the power LEDs on both the arudino and the powerboost. Heat them up with a soldering iron and they'll fall off or get brittle. Once brittle, a screwdriver and a little aggression will make the lights stop blinking. I was emboldened by my pile of spare parts. Don't try that if it's your only part. :)

Code

Arduino code using FastLED is here:
https://github.com/bobiam/blinky_jellyfish

Pattern can be advanced via serial (send "n" noquotes) or button (interrupt on pin 2). It's relatively trivial to add a serial bluetooth module like the cheap JY-MCU if you want to send patterns from your phone. I was happy with a button, personally.

description.header: Why is this a Work In Progress?
description.text:
So the biggest reason that this is marked a WIP is that I'm struggling with the main jellyfish dome.

Right now, mine's using a combination of the clips I posted, snipped to fit, hot-glued and welded to the dome and body. It's holding, but it isn't great and I don't expect it to survive for long, but I can lift it by the dome without it breaking off, so....we'll see.

Things I've tried:

  • Countersinking a nut into the main mast and gluing a bolt to the top of the inside of the jellyfish - too much stress, failed.
  • Using an assortment of clips to try to make simple closures inside the jellyfish - so far they're all breaking off

  • doublesided tape - ugly and not strong enough
    Things I plan to try:

  • velcro
  • fishing line (down to the middle section and up through a hole in the dome)
  • posting it on thingiverse and hoping someone comes up with something better?
Also, lots of hacking with a heat gun

If I were going to make another one, I might try it the same way. If I were going to make a few more, I'd update the 3d models. There's a lot of hotglue, heatgun, and "close enough" going on in this build. It's not something that should be started lightly. You won't take this model, print it, and snap it together. Expect to do some heavy modifications to the parts after you print them.

comments.author: plasmaton

comments.text: WOW! This is amazing! We're definitely going to make one of these; thanks for sharing your design!
comments.author: 3DCentralVA

comments.text: I printed the thing in natural pla, with some glow in the dark PLA for the center parts.  There's a fair bit of thermal welding and poking/prodding to make this one work, but I was really really happy with the way the light diffused around all of the electronics.  By pointing the neopixel ring down into the body, the whole thing radiates light pretty cleanly.

title: ZTE Speed Mount with USB Relief

description.text: This is a mount for the ZTE Speed for use on FTC robots. This design incorporates a USB Strain reliever, which is a hole for the USB cable that uses no zip ties. The mount comes in 2 pieces to save on material and for those who have smaller printers.

Notes:

Supports will be needed for the cable hole to make sure the hole isn't too small, unless your printer is really good at bridging.

print_settings.Notes:: This will print upright or on its side depending on where you want supports to be generated.

description.text:
[UPDATE 03-Nov-2016]
I recently received an unexpected upgrade to a G5, and to my surprise it's almost exactly the same size as the G4, and it fits in the cradle perfectly. So if you have a G5, feel free to print this. I plan on increasing the height slightly to give a little more clearance for the USB cable, as it is currently puts a little too much pressure on the connection.

I designed a charging cradle for my LG G4. Obviously it will only fit that phone or others very close to that size. It is slightly bigger than the actual phone to accommodate for a slim TPU case as well.

The rear foot is a little flimsy because of its length. I may thicken it up slightly if anyone has any issues, but it shouldn't be a problem.

The short version is identical except the top has been cut down so it's not quite as big.

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

This will print upright or on its side depending on where you want supports to be generated.

comments.text: Awesome, With those modifications I would print in a heartbeat :)

comments.text: Thanks, I will hopefully update this soon. Haven't had a lot of spare time lately so I haven't been 3d printing or modelling much at all. I need to fix that!

title: Mini Spool Adapter for MP Select Mini

description.text:
Simple spool holder designed to go on the stock arm to allow you to run smaller .25kg and .5kg spools that do not fit over the stock holder.

I've also included a foot so you can use it stand-alone for other printers as needed. If the foot fits loose, just shim it with a little piece of paper/tape. Or Glue it in if you're not using it with the Mini's stock arm.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

10%

comments.text: I printed this for my .5 kilo of AIO filament and the arms are not tall enough.This is the first roll of filament I ever bought so maybe that 1/2 a kilo is on a full sized spool.IDK.
comments.author: dugndeep

comments.text: what is that part on the right of the picture of all the parts
comments.author: atomickiller

comments.text: Where do you get the filament from that comes on small spools?  When I will be traveling with the MPSM I would like smaller spools for storage reasons.
comments.author: dougirwin212

comments.text: Frys electronics sells them. .25kg spools by MG Chemicals for $4.99. You can probably order them online as well.
comments.author: dougirwin212

comments.text: Any chance you could make/add taller arms to fit a full size spool? This is a great design and helps limit a lot of the drag from the stock arm.
comments.author: Salmmon

comments.text: Taller arms would not allow a full spool to sit sideways on the MP Select Mini, you would need taller and angled arms.
comments.author: Salmmon

comments.text:
Aha- wish I'd seen yours before making my own concoction. Great fun to see how independent thinkers solve the same problem. Nice design, very elegant.
I went with a 90º z-axis rotate on your spool orientation, and I slip my one-piece unit over the other end of the large-spool arm.
comments.author: ottaross

comments.text: HAHAHA yes you just saved me several hours worth of work thankyouthankyouthankyouthankyouthankyouthankyou.
