remixed_from.author: driz
remixed_from.title: Sony Xperia Z3 Mount For Playstation Dualshock 4

description.text:
This is a Very Very fast remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:575680 to fit both my phone and my roommate's. So I took the universal approach.
Note I did this in under 45 mins with another 30 mins for touch ups. I didn't put much time to make it look nice. I just wanted a phone mount.

You'll need another rubber band.. sorry :) See maniacal laugh here: http://i.imgur.com/yLwTABl.gif
As well as a M3x25 blot & nut. I was out so I used a drill bit to test it out :D

I also crafted a quick disconnect out of a small paperclip.

Some specs:
Min phone height: 45mm
Max phone height: ~90mm
Max phone thickness: 10mm (oops too thin for my phone. will revise later tomorrow.)
Min phone thickness: 8mm Use a sponge or foam to take up slack for thinner phones..

Files

My Inventor parts are included.
As well as STEP file exports
I also Included the 2 original unchanged ps4 brackets so you don't have to hunt for them :)

I'm up for suggestions and I hope this is useful for someone.

Update 1:

Added V2
I haven't printed this version yet as I can make the first work (barely). This version should be a little better. Let me know.
Top holder converted to a slider allowing for devices 0-20mm thick.
Extended bottom by 2mm and adjusted the tabs. Picture with dimensions attached.

New specs:
Min phone height: 45mm (unchanged)
Max phone height: ~90mm (unchanged)
Phone thickness top slider: 0-20mm
Max bottom phone thickness: 12.5mm
Min bottom phone thickness: 11mm Use a sponge or foam to take up slack for thinner phones.

Also added a Ps4_Mount_Lower_V2_Longer that has twice as long rods (+60mm) for tablets. Strength not guaranteed, but can be useful for small tablets. Theoretical max height: 150mm

Digital Hacksaw method

Basically I cut off the top half of the phone holder and attached 5mm x 30mm cylinders. Then created a new part that fitted over those cylinders. That part holds the top part of the phone.
The bottom part I cut off the shelf that the phone sits and extended it to fit thicker phones.

Fast and ugly. but functional

title: 6mm Belt Tensioners for Monoprice Select Mini 3D Printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Monoprice Select Mini has a pair of 6mm belts which are used for the X and Y movement. These belts each have a cheap spring tensioner which can flex under rapid changes in acceleration, leading to artifacts in the print. These belt tensioners can be used to replace the spring tensioners to apply constant tension to the belts and eliminate the flexible springs.

To use these tensioners, you will need a small cable tie fastener for each tensioner, which provides the clamping force to the tensioners and holds them in place.

Once you print these parts, clean them up and test fit them before attempting to install them. They should fit together snugly and securely. When that is done, take the spring clips off your belts with a pair of pliers and install the tensioners in their place as follows:

Start with the X tensioner, take a cable tie and the smaller half of the tensioner (important to use the smaller one) from the rear of the machine you should see the belt through the large slot. Place the smaller half of the X tensioner on the exposed belt on the side of the belt with the teeth in it. Place the second half of the tensioner on the other side of the belt and engage the cable tie to its lock. Draw the cable tie together to provide enough force to hold it in place but DO NOT tighten it fully. Now you slide the extruder hot end all the way as far toward the tower as it will go, and hold it there while you slide the belt tensioner along the belt as far to the opposite end of the gantry as it will go. Now fully tighten the cable tie lock. Use two pairs of pliers to get it as tight as you can. Trim of the excess cable tie. Slide the extruder hot end back and forth and make sure the tensioner does not hit on anything when it moves. If the tensioner hits the extruder, then you probably have the large and small parts swapped. The small one should be on the inside. If the extruder hot end is blocked from travelling to ether extent, then you probably did not have the hot end and tensioner at opposite ends of the gantry when you tightened the cable tie. In either case, just cut the cable tie and make corrections.

For the Y tensioner, lay the machine on it's back and pull the build plate as far forward as you can get it. Then take one of the halves of the Y belt tensioner and feed the cable tie through the slot. Pass the cable tie around the belt and put it through the slot in the other half of the Y belt tensioner. Engage the cable tie into its lock, but DO NOT tighten it yet. It's very important that you push the belt tensioner as far forward along the belt as you can get it. Try and get it right up against the metal lip of the build plate. Then tighten the tie wrap as tight as possible and trim off the excess. Sit the machine upright and slide the build plate backwards and listen for the limit switch to engage when it is almost completely to the rear. If the belt tensioner interferes with the travel of the build plate before the limit switch engages then you didn't get it fully forward before tightening. Cut off the cable tie and try again.

If you have trouble holding the clamps in place and tightening the cable ties (an extra set of hands would be useful) you can try using a clamp or locking pliers to compress the tensioner together until you get the cable tie tightened.

This worked great on my printer, and the Y belt tensioner provides enough tension now that eliminates the slop on the linear rod bearings which I was seeing before. I tried to provide enough tolerance in these parts to insure that variations in each printer would not be an issue, but since I only tested this on my printer, feedback on any tolerance issues would be welcome.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm Nozzle / 0.1mm Layer

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed these with 100% infill, as the print time was so short for such small parts that less infill did not make a significant difference.

Post Printing

Make sure to clean up the tensioner pairs and get rid of any excess plastic, and test fit the parts before installing. They should fit together snugly. Sand any irregularities until they fit.

comments.text: Well in my latest iteration I put threads directly in the model, for both the fan face, and the airpath adapator - they were printed at 100% infill (just the screw holes), but I was pleasantly surprised how effective the threads were. I would not expect them to last, but the were certainly good enough for a few mount/dismounts.
comments.author: hlide

comments.author: making_3d_changes

comments.text: Using freecad , there is a "Fasteners Workbench". If you have a hole in the model, you can "dock" a bolt/screw with the model. If you then make threads for the bolt, a subtraction will leave the negative threads in the model - so you can use proper bolts , not wood screws to attach the final printed object.
comments.author: hlide

comments.text: Thanks for the explanation! your work is still in progress or you think you finished it? if finished, are the files updated?
comments.author: making_3d_changes

comments.text: Some physics - the entry port on the phi is approx equiv to a 64mm fan ( sqrt(90*34/pi)). The exponential dropoff  was calculated (an extra support in the loft) so that the narrowing was approximately the same area. A fully specified shape of the loft to keep the transitition close to constant (3000mm^2), but a fast turn around is currently required.

Notes:

As the cooker operates by being heated by being in a microwave oven, I used PETG rather than PLA. ABS is probably satisfactory, too. PETG doesn't seem to be affected by the heat within the oven. UPDATE (Feb. 2017): after quite a few months of use, the PETG did tend to lose its shape. So better to use ABS if you can, as that should be better at withstanding raised temperatures.

Supports are small and are for the axles and ridges on the sloping area.
I used OpenSCAD; the code is not fully parametrised, and there are probably better ways of doing it.

author: Loki74

description.text:
Improved version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:807082

After using v2 for a while, I came to the conclusion that a death-grip on the phone was unnecessary. The fingers on the phone bracket have been slimmed down.

The original phone mount clip broke easily so it was replaced with a more robust solution.

The bracket on the transmitter has one leg to allow for the antenna to swivel to one side. I can now put the transmitter in my case without having to remove the mount.

The pieces were printed in PLA at .2 mm layer height and 75% density. The center mount piece is tapped with M3 threads. Printed pieces hold threads well. M3x25 socket head screws hold the clips and spacer to the center piece.

An M4x45 flat head screw holds the mount to the transmitter bracket. A nut secures the bolt to one side of the arm. The well in the thumb screw holds an M4 nut. An additional M3x15 screw bolts the mount pieces together.

description.text:
Geodesic Dome Connector for schedule 40 1" PVC pipes 3V

for detailed calculation of pipe length etc, refer to

http://www.acidome.ru/lab/calc/#7/12_Piped_D70_3V_R2_beams_30x30

you could scale this models to fit any size pipe theoretically.
5 pointed hub is for center of pentagon, 6 pointed hub for center of hexagon,
and 6 pointed hub with "P" is for the remaining, P should point to the pentagon.

protruding rods have diameter of 26.4 mm, which should fit tightly in schedule 40 pipe.

for 3/4" pipe, re-scale to 77.5% (not 75%)
for 1/2" pipe, re-scale to 57% (not 50%)

description.text:
Compatibility
I created it for F525 but it should work for most models. Please let me know.

1. august - v2 model

  • m4 mount holes are spaced evenly along the length, so doesn't matter how you fasten it to your MPCNC. (top and bottom are the same)
  • Removed some rounded edges in one end, which could pose a problem for ABS printing.
  • Created an image showing the dimensions

Note: I have not completely buildt my CNC yet, and thus havn't tested this mount in action yet.
All m4 and m5 bolts and nuts fits fine though.

Old and new

  • I've remixed the F-ToolMount stl file in Tinkercad.
  • The 4x mountholes have same placement.
  • The 4x mountholes now accomodate full M5 bolts and heads.
  • The Tool-Mount front faceplate is now level to accomodate most standard toolmounts.
  • Faceplate has rows of mounting-holes for m4 bolts.
  • The Mounting-holes on the faceplate is spaced with 23mm center to center of each other
  • There are cut-outs for standard m4 nuts on the backside for each mounting-hole.

Why this remix?

  • I found it rather difficult to make adapters for the original Mount-Plate.
  • I wanted 1 plate strong enough to mount full-sized Spindles, but also with versatility to easily attach tiny pens, syringes and anything else.

Printer:

JennyPrinter

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

55

Notes:

I just did it at 0,3mm layer height. I guess you can use most layer heights you want.

I recommend using 55% or more infill. I took from the original plate.

I printed mine in ABS as I ran out of black PLA. Worked great :)

Pre-mounting

Make sure you can fit M4 nuts into the mounting holes before you fasten the plate :)

M4 nuts inserted. Might want to give each a drop of superglue just to be sure they don't shake loose.

I just remixed the original stl file in Tinkercad

Imported and remixed the original STL file in Tinkercad.
Did the nuts in Autodesk Fusion 360 and imported to Tinkercad

comments.text: Hi, is it compatible with the 25.4mm version? Thank you!
comments.author: Palocho

comments.text: I have only tried it on 25mm. I guess you could easily attach it firmly onto 25,4mm though :)
comments.author: Palocho

comments.text:
if your having trouble designing for the original mount you could use my mounting plate and just add on to it.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1634262
comments.author: wbarber69

comments.text: That is rather inappropriate wbarber69 as my thing here solve exactly that problem...
comments.author: wbarber69

comments.text: You literally stated that you were having trouble designing for the original mount, and then you talk about needing it to be able to support all the tools, that's the point behind the 525 tool mount.  it was changed from the original mpcnc design for those exact reasons… I'm just trying to figure out why you redesigned it to do exactly the same thing.  I figured people would have a hard time trying to match the exact dimensions of Ryan's part so I made my blank tool mount to combat that.  what's inappropriate about sharing designs with one another?
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: The decent correct way is to put up your piece as a remix of the original tool-mount and let people decide whether they want my Mount-plate and the tool-mount they need.. or the originale curving mount-plate + your adapter + a tool mount they need... but posting here is just bad, and has nothing to do with sharing with each other.
comments.author: wbarber69

comments.text: If you just wanted to figure something out, a private message would do the trick.
comments.author: wbarber69

comments.text: I'm not competing with you, just offering up some fresh ideas.  i don't know if you tried to find something and couldn't, because thingiverse's search engine is incredibly broken.  you can only recently find the original mpcnc by typing in 'mpcnc'.  I didn't intend to piss you off, actually I thought we could be friends… my wife is Danish and she's also a Nielsen.  my part isn't a secondary piece that goes in between anything, it's up here so others can use it in their designs without having to start from scratch… since for some reason when Ryan posted his "universal tool mount blank" all that was in there was a schematic and a repost of his mk8 mount.  i also found it hard to design too, which is why I made my blank part available.  i do like yours, because of the placement of the backup nuts which seems like it would be way easier to reach around and secure than the way Ryan designed his.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: I'm sorry we seem to have miscommunicated. I just found that a surprising (or maybe not) number of people are trying to reap some easy profit on my work.. which I make for free and always share. Especially after I made some (for me) rather popular pieces, like my Belted Extruders http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764551
comments.author: wbarber69

comments.text: All my parts give credit where it is due.  i wasn't trying to make any money off your design.  i probably made mine first. I don't do this with the intent of making money.  but I will tip when I find a design that's useful.  ive never gotten any myself.  no competition here.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text:
My previous post was me trying to explain why I acted like I did, and also about using the "Remixes" section.
The word "Competition" was for lack of better term. I could have said "leech" instead, which is how it seemed to me at the time.
comments.author: wbarber69

comments.text: Your part is total replacement of the original. my part is available for designers to use in their design. so they don't have to try to reconstruct all the geometries and matching screw holes.  since there isn't any actual useful stls from Ryan himself to use his mount.  i used his mk8 mount and removed everything but the base sketch to match the rounded mount. then I used his schematics to align all the holes.  it only took about 10 minutes, but I figured it would save someone else a lot of figuring and measuring.  i guess since now onshape is more popular I should really post my step files instead of just the stl.

author: Dispenser

title: Flashforge Creator Pro 2016 Door Handle Draft/Warp Stopper

description.text:
Once I had a print warp at the front right hand side while a cold draft was passing through the house, I couldn't really see this being anything other than the hole where the door handle is so I designed this to hopefully resolve the issue.

This part MUST be printed in flexible material - it will not fit onto the printer with a hard plastic. I used 3D Prima TPE Flexible filament as it's cheaper than Ninjaflex and you get more of it.

Fits Flashforge Creator Pro 2016.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro 2016

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

comments.text: Worked and printed like a champ. Thanks a bunch
comments.author: thumper3dprints

comments.text: I am about to print one of these and see that you've suggest 100% infill? Surely less infill would increase both the flexibility and the level of insulation?
comments.author: nigelayres

comments.text: how well did the ffcp 2016 cope with flexible filament, i thought you needed a new extruder for that?
comments.author: sej7278

comments.text: It's variable depending on which way the way the wind is blowing with semi-flex. I recommend "ninjaflex cheetah" as the most easy to print flexible filament, although it is pricey and one of the more rigid flexible filaments.

The original model (and the one attributed to Tobz) was created by sgillford_at_gmail.com. I made numerous modifications to make it printable.

I used NetFabb and Microsoft 3D Builder to create and error-check the parts. Although not yet fully tested, they are fully manifold and should be printable without issue.

With that said, the parts all require support, which may prove challenging to remove. I found the interior a very difficult print. You are likely to have the best results if you print it as large as possible, and/or cut the interior into top and bottom pieces. Consider using the custom support in Meshmixer (or dissolvable support, if you have a dual-head printer).

I recommend printing the top and bottom shell pieces in yellow and the interior (and optional lower hatch) in gray or silver.

The picture is of my first printed version (made solid with MeshMixer, then printed with 0% infill and 3 shells in GP3D Yellow PLA on a Replicator 2), with the interior details and lights Photoshopped in. This inspired me to actually produce a detailed interior. The hatch on the bottom is separate, and covers a hole for a display stand (like this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1299040). It might also look good emerging from a splash like this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:192007.

The lower shell has holes for lights and there's plenty of room inside the shell for the necessary wiring, so go for it!

The chairs and people shown in the photo are not included.

July 31 update: Incorrectly sized parts have been fixed. Also, an error in the bottom shell has been fixed. A one-piece model has also been added. Print the one-piece model as shown in the last photo with 0% infill, 3 shells, raft and support ON.

title: Dremel Circle Cutter for Work Station

description.text:
For Dremel 220-01 Rotary Tool Work Station.

This Thing provides a center for your circular cutouts. A Nail may be used as center guide.

After printing make sure it fits snugly into the center hole of the work station. In case it does not fit you can adjust this setting via the customizer.

If you want to use anything else than a nail as center guide, you can change the diameter of the center hole in the customizer to fit a M3 screw for example.

comments.text: I will do this the next time I use it. But basically you center your sheet of material with a nail or something similar. Then you drill a pilot hole at the radius you want to cut. You then setup your cutting tool into the drilled hole and start turning your material slowly.

remixed_from.title: OctoPrint Raspberry Pi Rig 3.5" PiTFT Touch Display

title: Prusa i3 Rework X-carriage with 44mm spacing for Zonestar P802Q

description.text:
Remix from Prusa i3 Rework X-carriage with additional holes for Wade's extruder by AndrewBCN.

The X axis rods of Zonestar P802Q are 44 mm apart instead of 45 mm. In addition to the modified spacing I also removed the holes for Wade's extruder as the printer comes with a Bowden extruder.

comments.text: So are the holes here just a standard NEMA17 mount?
comments.author: kyouteki

author: kilpelaj

description.text:
I created this set of two cutters for needs of my house insulating works. One of the cutters cuts holes under pins and the second one cuts off cups to cover those pins. This method is the best way to:

  • prevent from the occurrence of condensation of water vapor or frosting on surface of plastic pins,
  • prevent from the occurrence of thermal bridges on the wall,
  • prevent from the concavity and convexity on the facade,
  • prevent from the ugly effect of "ladybug" on the facade.

Hole cutter cuts holes 20mm deep and with diameter 65mm.

To fix it on cordless drill it requries typical bolt and nut with M8 screw under 13mm wrench.

title: Battery holder 4xAA Square
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Just another battery support, but square. It is based on 4 AA batteries.
For connections I used the leftover crimp connectors (https://www.pololu.com/product/1931) .
To stay glued connections, you can push softly the metal part into the plastic with the hot soldering iron (the welder mustn't touch plastic) to soften it a little. That and black tape should be well attached.

------------------------------------------------- (ES)

Otro soporte para batería, pero en cuadrado. Es para 4 pilas tipo AA.
Para las conexiones he usado el sobrante de los conectores para crimpar (https://www.pololu.com/product/1931).
Para que se queden pegadas las conexiones, con el soldador caliente empujamos suavemente la parte de metal hacia el plástico (sin que el soldador toque el plástico) para que lo reblandezca un poco. Con eso y cinta negra debería quedar bien pegado.

Original wind wheel mounts cracked for me and snapped under load. Printing in PLA could solve that, but I have this spool of ABS I want to get rid of. Wanted design which is more forgiving to printing errors.

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 original kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

200 um

Notes:

Printed with support on screw holes. If you have bridges tuned, should be okay without them.

4 perimeters and 5 top/bottom layer for strength.

Used Slic3r modifiers to make base plate 100 % infill and middle leg with head higher infill then side legs.
http://slic3r.org/blog/modifier-meshes

Took measurements of original and prepare my peace as drop in replacement.
Wanted to print it on side to to avoid delamination under load.
Used 3 mm spacer from original set I had lying over to offset wind wheel.

title: Scalar - GoPro Mount for double aluminum Heatbed

description.text:
Description

This is a GoPro mount for Scalar XL 3D printers.
Scalar XL has 2 models of Heatbed.

  • 1 model with Wooden plater at the bottom
  • 1 Model with an Aluminum plate at the bottom.

This GoPro mount is for the model with the aluminum sheet at the bottom.

What you will need

You will need

  • 1 M3 Hex nut
  • 1 M3X12mm screw.

Have a great printing experience.

3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers

You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS

title: Improved open hinge for QIDI printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I really like the open hinge concept and I took it a couple steps further.
Here are two added features:

1 - Keeps the door open; when the door if fully open, slide to the right to lock the door into the open position
2 - Hinge only separates @ 30 degrees from vertical. The hinge will not let go of the door unless the door is almost all the way open. This means through most of the motion of opening, the door will stay where it is. Also the door will not come off while in the fully opened and locked position. Makes one-handed opening much easier because the door doesn't accidentally separate.

Note: The best orientation to print, for me, is as shown in the 3rd photo of the orange models.

Enjoy!

Printer:

QIDI

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100

Notes:

I printed in PETG with 100 % infill. I'm sure you can get away with less infill. I also used supports but it seems they were not necessarily needed.

I used an NPN sensor, so I used +12V and GND from the PSU and connected that to the sensor, then I used the two resistors as described in the video to reach ~3.5V and connected that to the signal-pin on the board (you can figure out which one the signal pin is by checking the backside of the board. title: Body for small USB Li-Ion headlamp charger

description.text:
On headlamps driven by 1 Li-Ion battery it is common to see 3.5mm 'barrel' socket to plug the charger (of course you can just take out your battery and charge it in external charger, but using internal is easier).

I've just take the cheap Li-Ion charging controller PCB and added 3.5mm plug, and made the box to glue it alltogether.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator 2x

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The model includes the whole part.
You need to split it, and then turn the lid part upside down (to lay flat on the table).

Vitamins

The PCB for usb charger is here.

Also you need the 'barrel plug' - outer dia 3.5mm, inner 1.35mm. I've used one soldered out from Nokia's old charger.

You can seal ready charger either with glue (when printing in ABS), either with screws.

Solder the plug to pcb with small (1-2cm) wires; then put the pcb and the plug into the box and attach the lid with glue or screws.

title: Oat Bar Press - For kids treats

description.text:
Please tip as all the tips go to a charitable cause!

UPDATE:
Press and Release are both 1mm too big on the sides and will not slide into main body. Scale for the time being, I will upload new files asap.

Oaty Bar Press for kids treats

Makes 7x2 (cm) bars and unit is about 8x3x3 (excluding press)

Comes in three parts;
Holder/Base - Main body of unit
Release - Inserts into the main body (holes will match up) and is used to release oaty mix once pressed
Press - Press unit with handle to press mix to a 0.5-1cm thickness onto Release inside the main base.

Print in food safe PLA (or normal PLA) and make sure to wash and disinfect after any use with Milton or similar.

Print at the highest resolution as you can so you reduce the chance of particles getting stuck. Must be as smooth as possible.

print_settings.Notes:: SMARTFIL ABS FIREPROOF

description.text:
Enclosure for the power supply SL Power GPC130BG used by a Nexus 670 FTIR spectrometer.

It was designed by customizing the Cool PCB Enclosure.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

For power supplies, I recommend the use of this filament: SMARTFIL ABS FIREPROOF

1. Vertical printing

Before reaching the hot zone of the nozzle the filament will pass through a white insulator piece. If the printing time is over 24 hours, retraction will make the filament get wider and wider at the teflon insulator (see figure 1).

If the filament diameter has deformed, it could cause unnecessary friction making it more difficult for the feeder to extrude properly and even to interrupt the printing when retraction is more frequent (see figure 2).

To avoid this issue, the best solution I found was to print the shields vertically and reduce the following parameters in cura:
Maximum Retraction Count = 30 (default = 90).
Retraction Distance = 2.25 mm (default = 4.5).
This setting prevents cura from doing excessive amounts of retractions on the same section of filament.

Eliminating retraction during printing is also possible and it will assure that filament accumulated in the white insulator is always fresh and new, keeping the original properties of the filament and reducing the risk of reaccumulation of already melted filament in this area.

Figure 1: Filament could become wider at the white teflon insulator, avoiding extrusion... Figure 2. Three different failed attempts. Printing got interrupted when retraction was more frequent... Figure 3: Correct position to print large shields.

2. Gluing parts

Each shield has been split in 2 parts.
The material used for this printing was PLA.
Cyanoacrylate + activator has been used to join them.
Verify that edges line perfectly up on both sides when gluing.

//---------------------------------------------------------------
//-- Openscad Cool PCB enclosure (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1665075)
//-- This is a simple fan cooled box, reusing ideas and code from the following excellent projects:
//--   + "The Ultimate box maker" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12Resolution391)
//--   + "Customizable Fan Grille" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52305).
//--   + "Radiator difussers" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:Resolution07)
//-- IMPORTANT NOTES:
//--   + The coordinate system is mostly center based in order to simplify the integration between different projects involved.
//--   + Fan grille's logos cannot be used through the Customizer App. In order to use Fan grille's logos, you must download both source code files and use Openscad instead.
//-- Please, refer to original projects for additional documentation and samples.
//-- Version: 1.0
//-- Aug-2016
//---------------------------------------------------------------
//-- Released under the GPL3 license
//---------------------------------------------------------------

//---------------------------------------------------------------
//-- CUSTOMIZER PARAMETERS
//---------------------------------------------------------------

// - Coque

// - Reinforcements of corners

/* [VISIBILITY] */

// - CounterShield Visibility
CounterShield_Visible = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]

/* [EXTERNAL_BOX_DIMENSIONS] */
// - Longueur - Length

/* [INTERNAL_BOX_PARAMETERS] */
// - Epaisseur - Shield thickness  
Shield_thickness = 5;

// - 
honeycomb_height = 4;
// - Epaisseur rail - Rail thickness  
rail_thickness = 4;
// - Hauteur rail - Rail height
rail_height = 4;
// - 
reed_hexagon_diameter = 20;
// - 
honeycomb_hexagon_thickness = 3;
// - Number of lateral screws
n_screws = 4;
// -
lateral_screw_diameter = 1.3;
// - Displacement of hexagonal mesh in vertical walls in case antireed leaves the area too unmeshed. (rhd+hht)/2 = (reed_hexagon_diameter + honeycomb_hexagon_thickness)/2
// - Hexagonal mesh displacement range: [ -(rhd+hht)/2, (rhd+hht)/2] 
deltaH = -8; 

/* [EXTERNAL_BOX_PARAMETERS) ] */
// - Diamètre flocon - Flake diameter
flake_dia = 10;
// - Epaisseur flocon - Flake thickness
flake_thick = 1;
// - Flake height
flake_height = Shield_thickness + honeycomb_height;
// - M3 nut's diameter (accross corners)
M3_dia = 6.1; // M3 standard = 6.01
// - M3 nut's diameter (accross corners)
M3_washer_dia = 9.1; // DIN-9021 = 9.01
// - Decoration-Holes width (in mm)
Vent_width = 1;//Obsolete

// - Diamètre coin arrondi - Fillet diameter  
Fillet = 12;//[0.1:16] 
// - lissage de l'arrondi - Fillet smoothness  
Resolution = 128;//[1:256] 

/* [BOTTOM_SHIELD_ITEMS] */
// - Bottom Fan Grill
BFan_Grill_item = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Bottom PCB1
BPCB1_item = 1;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Bottom PCB2
BPCB2_item = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Bottom PCB3

// - Pillar #1
Pillar1_item = 1;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Pillar #2
Pillar2_item = 1;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Pillar #3
Pillar3_item = 1;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Pillar #4

// - Pillar #5

// - Pillar #6
Pillar6_item = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]

/* [TOP_SHIELD_ITEMS] */
// - Top Fan Grill
TFan_Grill_item = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Top PCB1
TPCB1_item = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Top PCB2
TPCB2_item = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Top PCB3
TPCB3_item = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Top PCB4
TPCB4_item = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]

/* [REAR_PANEL_ITEMS] */
// - Rear Fan Grill
RFan_Grill_item = 1;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Rear Hexagonal_grid_item
RHexagonal_grid_item = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - 
rear_hexagon_diameter = 10;
// -
rear_hexagon_thickness = 3;
// - Tolérance - Tolerance (Panel/rails gap)
fitting_factor = 0.99;
// -
panel_thickness = 4.5;
// - Rear Fuse item
RFuse_item = 1;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Rear Plug_item
RPlug_item = 1;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Rear Switch_item
RSwitch_item = 1;// [0:No, 1:Yes]
// - Rear USB_item
RUSB_item = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]

/* [FRONT_PANEL_ITEMS] */
// - Panneau avant - Front panel
// - Text you want
txt = "Cool Box";           
// - Font size  
TxtSize = 3;                 
// - Font  
Police ="Arial Black"; 
// - Texte façade - Front text
Main_Text_Panel = 0;// [0:No, 1:Yes]

/* [COMMON_FEET_PARAMETERS) ] */
//All dimensions are from the center foot axis

// - Heuteur pied - Feet height
PCBFootHeight = 15;
// - Diamètre pied - Foot diameter
PCBFootDia = 10;
// - Diamètre trou - Hole diameter
PCBFootHole = 3.5;  

// - Power Supply Heuteur pied - Power Supply Feet height
PSF_Height = 25;
// - Power Supply Feet external diameter
PSF_ext_dia = 15;
// - Power Supply Feet internal diameter
PSF_int_dia = 3.5; // 6-32 UNC
// - Power Supply Feet base hole diameter
PSF_bh_dia = 7.5;
// - Power Supply Feet Fillet
PSF_Fillet = 12;
// - Power Supply Feet base hole height
PSF_bh_height = PSF_Height - 4;

// - Pillar height
Pillar_Height = Box_Height/2 - Shield_thickness;
// - Pillar external diameter
Pillar_ext_dia = 20;
// - Pillar internal diameter
Pillar_int_dia = 3.05; // M3
// - Pillar base hole diameter
Pillar_bh_dia = M3_washer_dia; // M3 standard = 6.01

Pillar_top_thick = 7;
// - Pillar Fillet
Pillar_Fillet = 12;
// - Pillar base hole height
Pillar_bh_height = Pillar_Height - Pillar_top_thick;

/* [POWER_SUPPLY_FEET_PARAMETERS) ] */

PS_PosX = 0;
// - PS Center Y Position
PS_PosY = 0;

// - Largeur PS Boite - PS Box Width
PS_box_width = 215.9;
// - Heuteur PS Boite - PS Box height
PS_box_height = 50.8;

// - PCB Center Y Position
PCB1_PosY = - (Box_Length/2 - 37);
// - Longueur PCB - PCB Length
PCB1_Length = 35;
// - Largeur PCB - PCB Width

/* [PCB2_FEET_PARAMETERS) ] */

// - PCB Center Y Position

PCB3_Length = 0;
// - Largeur PCB - PCB Width
PCB3_Width = 0;
// - Heuteur PCB - PCB height
PCB3_Height = 0;

/* [PCB4_FEET_PARAMETERS) ] */

PCB4_PosX = 0;
// - PCB Center Y Position
PCB4_PosY = 0;
// - Longueur PCB - PCB Length
PCB4_Length = 0;
// - Largeur PCB - PCB Width
PCB4_Width = 0;
// - Heuteur PCB - PCB height
PCB4_Height = 0;

/* [PILLAR_PARAMETERS) ] */
// - Center X Position
BPillar1_PosX = 60;
// - Center Y Position
BPillar1_PosY = 125;
// - Center X Position
BPillar2_PosX = -60;
// - Center Y Position
BPillar2_PosY = 125;
// - Center X Position
BPillar3_PosX = 60;
// - Center Y Position
BPillar3_PosY = -125;
// - Center X Position
BPillar4_PosX = -60;
// - Center Y Position
BPillar4_PosY = -125;
// - Center X Position
BPillar5_PosX = 0;
// - Center Y Position
BPillar5_PosY = 0;
// - Center X Position
BPillar6_PosX = 0;
// - Center Y Position
BPillar6_PosY = 0;

// - Center X Position
TPillar1_PosX = - BPillar1_PosX;
// - Center Y Position
TPillar1_PosY = BPillar1_PosY;
// - Center X Position
TPillar2_PosX = - BPillar2_PosX;
// - Center Y Position
TPillar2_PosY = BPillar2_PosY;

TPillar3_PosX = - BPillar3_PosX;
// - Center Y Position
TPillar3_PosY = BPillar3_PosY;

// - Center Y Position

// - Center X Position
TPillar6_PosX = - BPillar6_PosX;
// - Center Y Position
TPillar6_PosY = BPillar6_PosY;

//FAN GRILLE PARAMETERS

/* [FAN_GRILL_PARAMETERS) ] */
//All dimensions are from the center foot axis
// - Center X position
FanPosX = 10;
// - Center Y position
FanPosY = 0;
// - Longueur Fan - Fan Length
FanLength = 71.5;
// - Largeur Fan - Fan Width
FanWidth = 71.5;
// - Heuteur Fan - Fan height
FanHeight = 26;
// - Heuteur pied - Feet height
FanFootHeight = 15;
// - Diamètre pied - Foot diameter
FanFootDia = 8;
// - Diamètre trou - Hole diameter
FanFootHole = 3;  
// - Diamètre Fan - Fan diameter
FanDia = 80;  

// - Size of the inner icon or text
innerIconDiameter = 45; // [0:50]
// - Diameter of the circle
inner_circle_diameter =30;
// - Thickness of the Inner Vanes which should be less than outside frame thickness
innerThickness = (FanFootHeight+Shield_thickness)*3/4;  
// - How much thicker or thinner would you like the inner Logo to Be than the Innver Vane Thickness?
logoThickness = 1;
// -    
innerLogoThickness = logoThickness + innerThickness;

// - Number of Vanes
vaneCount = 12; // [1:45]   
// - Width of Vanes
vaneWidth = 1; // [1:45]
// - Number of Rings
numberOfRings = 6; // [0:45]
// - Ring Width
ringWidth = 1; // [1:45]

// - some calculated values
vane_angle = 360 / vaneCount;
// - ring_spacing defines the CENTER of each ring (radius)
ring_spacing = (FanDia - inner_circle_diameter + ringWidth) / (numberOfRings + 1)/2;
// - ring_spacing = FanDia;

//HEXAGONAL GRID PARAMETERS

/*[HEXAGONAL GRID]*/
// - 
area_width = 80;
// - 
area_length = 80;
// - 
hexagon_radius = 5;  
// - 
hexagon_thickness = Shield_thickness;  
// - 
hexagon_extra_distance = 0;

comments.text:
Unfortunately first two printings of the shield were interrupted when vertical walls began to be printed.
Both attempts ended with a blocked nozzle... :-((
I reached the conclusion that the walls are too far away from each other and the type of PLA used is very sensible to changes in the temperature of the print head.
Next time, I will print it in vertical position, like figure 3 at the Recommendations section.
comments.author: valba

This is a set of mud guards for the CP215KOA Frame. I have the unibody baseplate, not sure if it fits the frame where you can change individual arms.

The propellers shoot a lot of gras and other debris into the front and back opening of the pod, these mud guards help keeping the inside of the pod clean and protect the electronics.

i print these with 100% infill to make them tough.
